He founded the world's largest private luxury brand, transforming the fashion industry.
Celebrities described Armani as someone who does not follow trends.
Armani's legacy includes dominating fashion on Hollywood's red carpets.

clusters.title: European leaders press Trump over peacekeeper plan for Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: European Leaders Discuss Ukraine Security with Donald Trump

items.title: European leaders press Trump over peacekeeper plan for Ukraine
items.standfirst: Leaders ask president on call to detail security guarantees US could give to European force in event of ceasefireEuropean leaders have made fresh efforts to pin down Donald Trump on the level of support he is willing to give Ukraine to push back a Russian advance, and asked him to detail the security guarantees he would provide to any European peacekeeping force inside Ukraine in the event of a lasting ceasefire.European leaders spoke with Trump by video call on Thursday after first holding a meeting of the so-called “coalition of the willing” in Paris, co-chaired by Emmanuel Macron and Keir Starmer. Continue reading...
items.content: Leaders ask president on call to detail security guarantees US could give to European force in event of ceasefireEuropean leaders have made fresh efforts to pin down Donald Trump on the level of support he is willing to give Ukraine to push back a Russian advance, and asked him to detail the security guarantees he would provide to any European peacekeeping force inside Ukraine in the event of a lasting ceasefire.European leaders spoke with Trump by video call on Thursday after first holding a meeting of the so-called “coalition of the willing” in Paris, co-chaired by Emmanuel Macron and Keir Starmer. Continue reading...

items.title: Macron Says 26 Nations to Back Security Guarantees for Ukraine
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron said 26 countries had pledged to provide Ukraine with security guarantees in the event of a ceasefire with Donald Trump stopping short of committing to US backstop. Read more:…
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron said 26 countries had pledged to provide Ukraine with security guarantees in the event of a ceasefire with Donald Trump stopping short of committing to US backstop. Read more:…

items.title: Macron says 26 countries ready to send troops for Ukraine ceasefire
items.standfirst: The French president also says US support for the "Coalition of the Willing" would be finalised in the coming days.
items.content: The French president also says US support for the "Coalition of the Willing" would be finalised in the coming days.

items.title: 26 nations pledge post-war security support for Ukraine, Macron says
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that 26 countries have pledged post-war military support to Ukraine after any ceasefire deal with Russia. Macron said the planned deployments aim to ensure security, not provoke conflict. With US backing expected to be finalised soon, Ukraine's President Zelensky called the move a major step forward.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that 26 countries have pledged post-war military support to Ukraine after any ceasefire deal with Russia. Macron said the planned deployments aim to ensure security, not provoke conflict. With US backing expected to be finalised soon, Ukraine's President Zelensky called the move a major step forward.

items.title: Europe’s security impacts the US: EU holding on to hope Trump won’t ‘sell Ukraine down the river’
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has announced the twenty-six countries who have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia. Meanwhile, Macron assures that the United States have been clear on their will to take part in the security guarantees offered to Ukraine. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective Delano D'Souza welcomes John Lough, Associate Fellow for the Russia and Eurasia Program at Chatham House.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has announced the twenty-six countries who have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia. Meanwhile, Macron assures that the United States have been clear on their will to take part in the security guarantees offered to Ukraine. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective Delano D'Souza welcomes John Lough, Associate Fellow for the Russia and Eurasia Program at Chatham House.

items.title: Macron says 26 countries offer to participate in Ukraine post-war security
items.standfirst: Twenty-six countries have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia, French President Emmanuel Macron said Thursday. "We have today 26 countries who have formally committed -- some others have not yet taken a position -- to deploy as a 'reassurance force' troops in Ukraine, or be present on the ground, in the sea, or in the air," Macron told reporters at a joint press conference with Volodymyr Zelensky following a meeting of allies in Paris.
items.content: Twenty-six countries have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia, French President Emmanuel Macron said Thursday. "We have today 26 countries who have formally committed -- some others have not yet taken a position -- to deploy as a 'reassurance force' troops in Ukraine, or be present on the ground, in the sea, or in the air," Macron told reporters at a joint press conference with Volodymyr Zelensky following a meeting of allies in Paris.

items.title: Zelensky meets European leaders in Paris over Ukraine security guarantees
items.standfirst: European leaders and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky were meeting in Paris on Thursday to agree security guarantees for Kyiv in the event of a peace accord with Russia to end the three-and-a-half-year war sparked by Moscow's 2022 invasion. The guarantees by the so-called coalition of the willing, which remain under wraps but are expected to include ramped-up training for the Ukrainian army and deployment of troops by some European states, have angered Russia.
items.content: European leaders and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky were meeting in Paris on Thursday to agree security guarantees for Kyiv in the event of a peace accord with Russia to end the three-and-a-half-year war sparked by Moscow's 2022 invasion. The guarantees by the so-called coalition of the willing, which remain under wraps but are expected to include ramped-up training for the Ukrainian army and deployment of troops by some European states, have angered Russia.

items.title: Trump says Putin and Zelenskyy are 'not ready' for peace as European powers meet
items.standfirst: France's Macron is hosting Ukraine's Zelenskyy in Paris with hopes he will underwrite "security guarantees" in the event of a ceasefire with Russia.
items.content: France's Macron is hosting Ukraine's Zelenskyy in Paris with hopes he will underwrite "security guarantees" in the event of a ceasefire with Russia.

ai_summary: European leaders pressed Donald Trump on security guarantees for Ukraine in a video call.
Twenty-six countries pledged post-war military support for Ukraine, according to Macron.
The US backing for the "Coalition of the Willing" is expected to be finalized soon.
Macron stated the planned deployments aim to ensure security, not provoke conflict.
The EU hopes Trump will not withdraw support for Ukraine.

items.title: Watch: RFK Jr. gets into heated exchange with Sen. Maggie Hassan at hearing
items.standfirst: HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Sen. Maggie Hassan, a Democrat from New Hampshire, got into a heated exchange during a Senate Finance Committee hearing. Kennedy accused Hassan of making things up when confronting him about vaccines, to which she responded, "Sometimes when you make an accusation, it's kind of a confession."
items.content: HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Sen. Maggie Hassan, a Democrat from New Hampshire, got into a heated exchange during a Senate Finance Committee hearing. Kennedy accused Hassan of making things up when confronting him about vaccines, to which she responded, "Sometimes when you make an accusation, it's kind of a confession."

items.title: RFK Jr. faces heated questions on CDC, vaccines at Senate hearing
items.standfirst: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. defended firing the director of the CDC at a hearing before a Senate committee on Thursday.
items.content: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. defended firing the director of the CDC at a hearing before a Senate committee on Thursday.

items.title: RFK Jr. denies pressuring ousted CDC director to preapprove vaccine changes
items.standfirst: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy denied pressuring the ousted CDC director to preapprove vaccine recommendations.
items.content: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy denied pressuring the ousted CDC director to preapprove vaccine recommendations.

items.title: Watch: Sen. Tillis points out RFK Jr.'s contradictory statements during Senate hearing
items.standfirst: Sen. Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina, pointed out some contradictory statements HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has made and asked him to clarify his stance on Operation Warp Speed and explain why he fired the CDC director.
items.content: Sen. Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina, pointed out some contradictory statements HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has made and asked him to clarify his stance on Operation Warp Speed and explain why he fired the CDC director.

items.title: Watch: Sen. Barrasso tells RFK Jr. he's "deeply concerned" about his vaccine approach
items.standfirst: GOP Sen. John Barrasso of Wyoming said he's "deeply concerned" about HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s approach to vaccine recommendations. During the Senate hearing, Barrasso questioned Kennedy about his next steps on approaching vaccine guidance.
items.content: GOP Sen. John Barrasso of Wyoming said he's "deeply concerned" about HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s approach to vaccine recommendations. During the Senate hearing, Barrasso questioned Kennedy about his next steps on approaching vaccine guidance.

items.title: HHS Secretary RFK Jr. wraps heated Senate testimony
items.standfirst: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. testified before the Senate on Thursday amid continued turmoil at the CDC. CBS News congressional correspondent Caitlin Huey-Burns has more.
items.content: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. testified before the Senate on Thursday amid continued turmoil at the CDC. CBS News congressional correspondent Caitlin Huey-Burns has more.

items.title: Watch: Sen. Cantwell calls RFK Jr. a charlatan and blasts mRNA vaccine research cuts
items.standfirst: Washington Sen. Maria Cantwell called out Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. at a Senate committee hearing Monday, accusing him of perpetrating hoaxes and blasting him for cuts to mRNA vaccine research.
items.content: Washington Sen. Maria Cantwell called out Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. at a Senate committee hearing Monday, accusing him of perpetrating hoaxes and blasting him for cuts to mRNA vaccine research.

items.title: Watch: Sanders, RFK Jr. get into testy exchange over COVID vaccine, CDC director's firing
items.standfirst: Sen. Bernie Sanders questioned HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. about his views on the COVID-19 vaccine, which President Trump has touted as one of the greatest inventions in medicine. Sanders also suggested he will call fired CDC Director Susan Monarez to testify before Congress.
items.content: Sen. Bernie Sanders questioned HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. about his views on the COVID-19 vaccine, which President Trump has touted as one of the greatest inventions in medicine. Sanders also suggested he will call fired CDC Director Susan Monarez to testify before Congress.

items.title: Watch: Sen. Bennet confronts RFK Jr. about claims made by new vaccine panel members
items.standfirst: Sen. Michael Bennet pressed Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. during a Senate Finance Committee hearing about past claims made by new members of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices.
items.content: Sen. Michael Bennet pressed Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. during a Senate Finance Committee hearing about past claims made by new members of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices.

items.title: Cassidy blasts RFK Jr. for moves contradicting success of Trump's Operation Warp Speed
items.standfirst: Louisiana Sen. Bill Cassidy blasted Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for his decisions to cut funding for mRNA vaccine research, pointing to President Trump's 2020 Operation Warp Speed that helped lead to the creation of a COVID-19 vaccine.
items.content: Louisiana Sen. Bill Cassidy blasted Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for his decisions to cut funding for mRNA vaccine research, pointing to President Trump's 2020 Operation Warp Speed that helped lead to the creation of a COVID-19 vaccine.

items.title: Watch: Sen. Wyden questions RFK Jr. about CDC director's firing
items.standfirst: Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon questioned HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. about the firing of CDC Director Susan Monarez and whether he pressured her to reapprove vaccine recommendations, which Kennedy denied.
items.content: Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon questioned HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. about the firing of CDC Director Susan Monarez and whether he pressured her to reapprove vaccine recommendations, which Kennedy denied.

items.title: Watch: RFK Jr. defends CDC shake-up, MAHA agenda during opening statement at Senate hearing
items.standfirst: During his opening statement before the Senate Finance Committee, Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. defended his Make America Healthy Again agenda and the recent firings and resignations at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
items.content: During his opening statement before the Senate Finance Committee, Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. defended his Make America Healthy Again agenda and the recent firings and resignations at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

ai_summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. faced questions about CDC firings and vaccine changes.
Senator Mark Warner pressed Kennedy on Covid facts during the hearing.
Kennedy and Senator Maggie Hassan had a heated exchange about vaccines.
Kennedy denied pressuring the ousted CDC director to preapprove vaccine changes.
Kennedy defended firing the director of the CDC at the hearing.

clusters.title: Boy, 3, pulled from funicular crash that has shocked Portugal
clusters.neutral_headline: Lisbon Funicular Crash Death Toll Rises

items.title: Boy, 3, pulled from funicular crash that has shocked Portugal
items.standfirst: It is unclear what caused the crash in which 16 people died and more than 20 were injured, including many foreign nationals.
items.content: It is unclear what caused the crash in which 16 people died and more than 20 were injured, including many foreign nationals.

items.title: 'Out of control': Witnesses describe fatal Lisbon funicular crash
items.standfirst: At least 16 people were killed and 20 more injured, some critically, Portuguese authorities say.
items.content: At least 16 people were killed and 20 more injured, some critically, Portuguese authorities say.

items.title: What we know about Lisbon's deadly funicular crash
items.standfirst: At least 16 people died after a carriage on the city's famous Glória hillside railway derailed.
items.content: At least 16 people died after a carriage on the city's famous Glória hillside railway derailed.

items.title: Death toll rises in Lisbon funicular crash as investigators search for a cause
items.standfirst: The death toll in the crash of a Lisbon funicular popular with tourists rose to 17 on Thursday after two people died from their injuries while receiving hospital care, an emergency services official said. The cause of the derailment remained unclear and officials have declined to speculate on whether a faulty brake or a snapped cable may have prompted the descending streetcar to careen into a building.
items.content: The death toll in the crash of a Lisbon funicular popular with tourists rose to 17 on Thursday after two people died from their injuries while receiving hospital care, an emergency services official said. The cause of the derailment remained unclear and officials have declined to speculate on whether a faulty brake or a snapped cable may have prompted the descending streetcar to careen into a building.

items.title: Watch: BBC correspondent at scene of Lisbon funicular crash
items.standfirst: Local media reports suggest a cable came loose along the railway's route, causing it to lose control - a national day of mourning is being observed
items.content: Local media reports suggest a cable came loose along the railway's route, causing it to lose control - a national day of mourning is being observed

items.title: Lisbon streetcar crash death toll rises to 16 as Portugal observes day of mourning
items.standfirst: A national day of mourning began in Portugal Thursday, after at least 17 people were killed and 22 injured when a popular funicular railway derailed in Lisbon.
items.content: A national day of mourning began in Portugal Thursday, after at least 17 people were killed and 22 injured when a popular funicular railway derailed in Lisbon.

items.title: What we know so far about the Lisbon funicular crash
items.standfirst: Portuguese authorities have declared three days of mourning after Lisbon's iconic Gloria funicular crashed, killing 16 people and injuring 23.
items.content: Portuguese authorities have declared three days of mourning after Lisbon's iconic Gloria funicular crashed, killing 16 people and injuring 23.

items.title: At least 15 people killed and 18 injured in crash of funicular railway in Lisbon
items.standfirst: At least 15 people were killed and 18 were injured in a crash of a popular funicular railway in Lisbon, Portugal, on Wednesday, according to local authorities.
items.content: At least 15 people were killed and 18 were injured in a crash of a popular funicular railway in Lisbon, Portugal, on Wednesday, according to local authorities.

ai_summary: A funicular crash in Lisbon resulted in at least 16 deaths and 20 injuries.
The cause of the funicular derailment remains unclear.
Authorities declared three days of mourning after the crash.
Local media suggests a cable came loose, causing the derailment.
The death toll rose to 17 after two people died from injuries.

clusters.title: Third earthquake hits Afghanistan as death toll rises above 2,200
clusters.neutral_headline: Earthquake Strikes Afghanistan, Death Toll Rises

items.title: Third earthquake hits Afghanistan as death toll rises above 2,200
items.standfirst: South-east of country rocked as rescuers struggle to find survivors of first quakeA magnitude 6.2 earthquake has shaken Afghanistan as the death toll from the devastating quake on Sunday rose to more than 2,200.It struck south-eastern regions on Thursday night, according to the Helmholtz Centre for Geosciences in Germany. It was not immediately clear how much damage there was. Continue reading...
items.content: South-east of country rocked as rescuers struggle to find survivors of first quakeA magnitude 6.2 earthquake has shaken Afghanistan as the death toll from the devastating quake on Sunday rose to more than 2,200.It struck south-eastern regions on Thursday night, according to the Helmholtz Centre for Geosciences in Germany. It was not immediately clear how much damage there was. Continue reading...

items.content: An aftershock hit the quake-hit area of Afghanistan on Thursday as aid organisations struggle to reach survivors.

ai_summary: A 5.6-magnitude earthquake struck Southern Afghanistan on Thursday.
A 6.2-magnitude earthquake hit southeastern Afghanistan.
The death toll from the earthquakes rose to 2,200.
Aid organizations are struggling to reach survivors.
The earthquake was recorded at a depth of 10 kilometers.

clusters.title: President of Northwestern University quits amid layoffs forced by Trump cuts
clusters.neutral_headline: Northwestern University President Resigns

items.title: President of Northwestern University quits amid layoffs forced by Trump cuts

clusters.title: Argentina recovers long-lost Italian painting looted by Nazis during WWII
clusters.neutral_headline: Nazi-Looted Painting Recovered in Argentina

items.title: Argentina recovers long-lost Italian painting looted by Nazis during WWII
items.standfirst: An Argentine federal court announced Wednesday that authorities had recovered the long-lost “Portrait of a Lady,” an 18th-century work by the Italian painter Giuseppe Ghislandi that was looted by the Nazis in World War II. Before the presentation of the giant gold-framed portrait Wednesday in the Argentine coastal city of Mar del Plata, the painting had not been seen publicly in 80 years.
items.content: An Argentine federal court announced Wednesday that authorities had recovered the long-lost “Portrait of a Lady,” an 18th-century work by the Italian painter Giuseppe Ghislandi that was looted by the Nazis in World War II. Before the presentation of the giant gold-framed portrait Wednesday in the Argentine coastal city of Mar del Plata, the painting had not been seen publicly in 80 years.

clusters.title: Thursday briefing: China flexes its muscle in the tussle for global dominance
clusters.neutral_headline: China Hosts Military Parade, Xi Speaks on Global Choices

items.title: Thursday briefing: China flexes its muscle in the tussle for global dominance
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: In hosting anti-western leaders at its largest ever military parade, Beijing sent a defiant message that will be heard loud and clear across the worldGood morning. All eyes have been on China this week as the second biggest global economy flexed its muscles.Dozens of world leaders, including from the global south, authoritarian pariah states and the EU, attended China’s largest ever military parade on Wednesday to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the war of resistance against Japanese aggression.UK news | Deputy PM Angela Rayner has admitted she underpaid stamp duty on her £800,000 seaside flat, after coming under intense pressure to be more transparent about her property arrangements.Russia | Vladimir Putin has invited Kim Jong-un to visit Russia during a lengthy meeting in Beijing on the sidelines of China’s biggest military parade, as Kim promised to do “everything I can to assist” Moscow.Police | The Metropolitan police have declined to drop their investigation into the comedy writer Graham Linehan for tweets about trans issues, and said that the law used by officers to detain him needs reviewing.Israel | Israeli drones dropped four grenades near UN peacekeepers in south Lebanon, the agency’s force said on Wednesday, in what it described as “one of the most serious attacks” on its personnel since a November ceasefire.Portugal | A day of national mourning has been declared in Portugal after at least 15 people were killed when Lisbon’s well-known Gloria funicular railway car derailed and crashed on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: In today’s newsletter: In hosting anti-western leaders at its largest ever military parade, Beijing sent a defiant message that will be heard loud and clear across the worldGood morning. All eyes have been on China this week as the second biggest global economy flexed its muscles.Dozens of world leaders, including from the global south, authoritarian pariah states and the EU, attended China’s largest ever military parade on Wednesday to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the war of resistance against Japanese aggression.UK news | Deputy PM Angela Rayner has admitted she underpaid stamp duty on her £800,000 seaside flat, after coming under intense pressure to be more transparent about her property arrangements.Russia | Vladimir Putin has invited Kim Jong-un to visit Russia during a lengthy meeting in Beijing on the sidelines of China’s biggest military parade, as Kim promised to do “everything I can to assist” Moscow.Police | The Metropolitan police have declined to drop their investigation into the comedy writer Graham Linehan for tweets about trans issues, and said that the law used by officers to detain him needs reviewing.Israel | Israeli drones dropped four grenades near UN peacekeepers in south Lebanon, the agency’s force said on Wednesday, in what it described as “one of the most serious attacks” on its personnel since a November ceasefire.Portugal | A day of national mourning has been declared in Portugal after at least 15 people were killed when Lisbon’s well-known Gloria funicular railway car derailed and crashed on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.title: Xi Jinping says world faces ‘peace or war’, as Putin and Kim join him for military parade
items.standfirst: Trump criticises victory day event as China caps off week of diplomatic grandstanding seen as rebuke to the westXi Jinping said the world was facing a choice between peace or war as he held China’s largest-ever military parade, joined by Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un in a show of defiance to the west.Putin and Kim, the authoritarian leaders of Russia and North Korea, were among dozens of world leaders who attended the parade, a massive display of military hardware and personnel, orchestrated to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression. Continue reading...
